option.name: title_text
option.value: Adapting in person to online classrooms

string_table.name: npxnabnsnfns10111001101
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Transitioning from the traditional classroom to the virtual world presents unique challenges, but with thoughtful planning and strategic use of technology, we can create engaging and effective online learning experiences. Today, we'll explore these challenges and discuss practical solutions to maximize student engagement." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Moving our lessons online brings inherent challenges. One of the most significant is the loss of face-to-face interaction. The spontaneous back-and-forth, the visual cues, and the immediate feedback we rely on in-person are often diminished in the online environment. This can lead to decreased spontaneous participation from students, making it harder to gauge their understanding and address their questions in real-time. Furthermore, attention spans can be shorter in online settings due to the numerous distractions students may face in their home environments. Ensuring tech accessibility and proficiency for all students is a crucial consideration. Not all students have equal access to technology or the same level of comfort with online platforms. Lets look into strategies that can help overcome these challenges. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="First, the lack of spontaneous participation in an online classroom is one of the most challenging obstacles in online classrooms. This is why building intentional collaboration is crucial. Interactive whiteboards, readily available in many online platforms like Miro, offer a fantastic tool for collaborative activities. Students can work together in real-time on shared documents or visual projects, mimicking the collaborative experience of a physical whiteboard. Using Google Docs or Sheets is also a great way to incorporate collaboration. Intentional break-out rooms can be useful for collaboration when meeting online, as students are often more likely to speak up in smaller settings. Discussions can also prove to be a good tool, but only when done right. So often, when we ask students to share in an online discussion it does not facilitate active collaboration. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="We can also increase meaning by providing students with a space to reflect on their own learning. Reflective journals or blogs can provide a space for students to process their learning, express their thoughts and feelings about the material, and develop their metacognitive skills. This can be particularly valuable in asynchronous courses, where opportunities for informal reflection might be limited." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="When it comes to attention spans and distractions at home, it is important to consider how interesting and meaningful content is. Thankfully, EdTech offers a wealth of tools to enhance online engagement. Gamification techniques, such as awarding badges or points for participation and achievement, can make learning more fun and motivating. Utilizing interactive content creation tools allows instructors to develop dynamic and engaging lessons that go beyond static text and images. Collaborative platforms, like Google Workspace or Microsoft Teams, provide shared spaces for students to work together on projects, share resources, and communicate effectively. CourseArc emphasizes the importance of choosing the right tools to support your specific learning objectives and activities." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Let's consider a few practical examples. Imagine you're teaching a history lesson on the Gold Rush. In an in-person class, you might have a large group discussion. Online, you could divide the class into smaller breakout rooms for synchronous discussions on specific aspects of the revolution. You could then use a collaborative platform, like Padlet, for each group to create a timeline of key events. Students could also contribute images and resources related to the era. Finally, you could incorporate a quiz using a gamified platform like Kahoot! to review the material." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Now, lets say that you are a science teacher looking to adapt a lab to a virtual classroom. In a traditional science lab, students would conduct hands-on experiments, mixing chemicals in beakers, carefully observing the resulting reactions, and meticulously recording their data in lab notebooks. To adapt this for an online environment, the instructor could utilize virtual lab simulations, accessible through platforms like ChemCollective or PhET, which allow students to manipulate virtual equipment, mix virtual chemicals, and observe virtual reactions, providing a safe and consistent experience for all learners. Alternatively, the instructor could record video demonstrations of the experiment, which students could then analyze, collecting data from the recording and answering related comprehension questions, perhaps even incorporating interactive quizzes embedded directly within the video. The students could then share their findings, compare results, and discuss potential sources of error, just as they would in a physical lab setting using an interactive whiteboard and screen sharing." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Or perhaps you are an English teacher, looking to continue peer editing between students when completing an essay. In a face-to-face English class, students might exchange printed drafts of their essays, providing written feedback directly on the papers. For an online adaptation, the instructor could leverage the collaborative features of Google Docs or Microsoft Word online, enabling students to share their essays digitally and utilize the "Suggesting" feature in Google Docs or "Track Changes" in Word to provide feedback directly within the document without altering the original text. Additionally, students could record short video or audio messages providing verbal feedback on their peers' essays for more personalized communication than written comments alone. To further structure the peer review process, the instructor could use online peer review platforms like Kritik or Peergrade, which provide structured workflows for feedback and allow students to rate and evaluate the quality of the feedback they receive, often offering rubrics and prompts to guide students in providing constructive criticism." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Adapting in-person lessons for online delivery requires careful consideration of the unique challenges and opportunities of the virtual environment. By implementing these strategies, leveraging EdTech effectively, and remaining flexible and responsive to student needs, as the resources highlight, we can create engaging and effective online learning experiences that foster active participation, promote deep understanding, and build a strong sense of community. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
